texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: When you create a CSR and private key to obtain an SSL certificate, the private key has some internal data called a modulus. This is integral to the security of your SSL encryption, but for this specific post, we will focus on one specific aspect.
texts.text: When you create a CSR and private key to obtain an SSL certificate, the private key has some internal data called a modulus. This is integral to the security of your SSL encryption, but for this specific post, we will focus on one specific aspect.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If your private key and certificate do not contain the same modulus, then Apache will sometimes refuse to start or it may not respond properly to SSL requests. You can check the modulus of your private key and SSL certificate with these commands:
texts.text: If your private key and certificate do not contain the same modulus, then Apache will sometimes refuse to start or it may not respond properly to SSL requests. You can check the modulus of your private key and SSL certificate with these commands:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# openssl rsa -noout -modulus -in server.key | openssl md5
# openssl x509 -noout -modulus -in server.crt | openssl md5
texts.text:
# openssl rsa -noout -modulus -in server.key | openssl md5
# openssl x509 -noout -modulus -in server.crt | openssl md5

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If the MD5 checksums match, then the certificate and key will work together. However, if they are different, then you cannot use them together. Generally, this means that you used the wrong CSR (that corresponded to some other private key) when you obtained/created your SSL certificate.
texts.text: If the MD5 checksums match, then the certificate and key will work together. However, if they are different, then you cannot use them together. Generally, this means that you used the wrong CSR (that corresponded to some other private key) when you obtained/created your SSL certificate.
